pullRequest.body:
Layer cake formulas currently exist for `ENNReal`-valued functions and Lebesgue integrals. This PR adds the most common version of the layer cake formula for integrable a.e.-nonnegative real-valued functions and Bochner integrals.

---

I don't know if the other (more general) versions of layercake should be similarly generalized. The proofs are basically similar, but the statements themselves become a bit unpleasant due to integrability requirements for something slightly complicated. I would therefore at least wait until they are needed.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

Followup in #7454

bors d+
Thanks!

bors d+
Thanks!
You shouldn't need to have a measurable space structure on `E` in the statement. If you need it in the proof, you can use `borelize E`. Also, you shouldn't need mu to be sigma-finite.
could you move the assumptions `f_intble` to all the lemmas that use it? Otherwise, the statements are harder to understand for someone just browsing through the file.
again, I don't see why sigma-finite should be relevant here.

In this actual layercake formula result, sigma-finiteness is needed because the proof of the layercake formula is at its heart an application of Fubini's theorem.

(One can trace back the necessity of the hypotheses in the current proof to first the most fundamental layercake formula `lintegral_comp_eq_lintegral_meas_le_mul_of_measurable` in the present file, and in its proof to Fubini's theorems `lintegral_lintegral_swap`).

You are completely right that including `[SigmaFinite μ]` in the `variable` line in this section is a mistake, none of the results except this very last one need this hypothesis.

Still I don't think that sigma-finiteness is relevant here: you could restrict your measure to the set where `f > 0` (which doesn't change anything to the desired formula), and this restricted measure is sigma-finite as the function is integrable. Maybe first state an auxiliary lemma assuming the measure is sigma-finite, and deduce the general case afterwards?
(See `MeasureTheory.Integrable.aefinStronglyMeasurable` and `AEFinStronglyMeasurable.exists_set_sigmaFinite`)
Oh, thanks, this seems like a nice strenghtening!

I wrote a proof without the sigma-finiteness assumption as you suggested.

The proof structure is in principle the same as before, except two observations `obs` and `obs'` are needed to reduce to the earlier case. Mathematically these two observations are trivial, but I failed to come up with short proofs. I'm probably missing some good ways of handling the a.e. properties and restrictions of measures here.

(The very first line is now a combination of the two relevant results you mentioned: `MeasureTheory.Integrable.aefinStronglyMeasurable` and `AEFinStronglyMeasurable.exists_set_sigmaFinite`. Thanks a lot for those! The former needed an extra import `Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Function.StronglyMeasurable.Lp`, but I think it should not be too problematic import creep in the layercake file.)
Can you remove `sigma-finite` from the docstring then?

Sorry, I forgot to update the docstring! I now fixed the docstring of this theorem and added a note in the module docstring. The module docstring starts by assuming sigma-finiteness, and I'd keep it that way unless you think it is misleading.

Thanks again! Getting rid of the sigma-finiteness assumption is a nice generalization that simply did not occur to me when writing this.

And sorry, still, that my proofs of `obs` and `obs'` are clumsy. Both sound like they should be one-liners and then they should be done in the middle of the proof, but if they are not one-liners, should they be separated to lemmas of their own? At least `obs` might have other uses. For `obs'`, I'd have to think about a formulation that has potential of being useful elsewhere. I will still at least think about this, but if you have a clear opinion about whether to separate these, I'll be happy to hear.
I will rewrite separating these as lemmas --- I believe it will be clearer and the golfing opportunities will also be more evident. I added label `awaiting_author` while I do the change.

I now found the existing result `Integrable.measure_ge_lt_top`, which was essentially identical to one of the lemmas I added. I removed the duplicate and reduce some of the new lemmas to this existing one.

I am tempted to rename this existing result and the `gt` counterpart here as `Integrable.measure_norm_ge_lt_top` and `Integrable.measure_norm_gt_lt_top`, respectively. Then the new ones, used in the layercake file, could be called `Integrable.measure_gt_lt_top`, `Integrable.measure_ge_lt_top` etc. The justification for the naming would be that the new ones have the `gt`/`ge` on values, whereas the old one has it for the norm of the value.

Is it ok to rename?
Yes, the rename makes perfect sense. Maybe move the other lemmas `Integrable.measure_ge_lt_top` and so on close to this one, for easier discoverability?

Is there a preferred spelling?

[`AEFinStronglyMeasurable.exists_set_sigmaFinite`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Function/StronglyMeasurable/Basic.html#MeasureTheory.AEFinStronglyMeasurable.exists_set_sigmaFinite) uses the LHS spelling.

[`set_integral_eq_integral_of_ae_compl_eq_zero`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Integral/SetIntegral.html#MeasureTheory.set_integral_eq_integral_of_ae_compl_eq_zero) uses the RHS spelling.

I have added `integral_eq_integral_restrict` as well as this equivalence `restrict_aeeq_zero_iff_ae_mem_eq_zero` essentially only for the reason to glue between the different spellings in the above two results.
I'd say `ae_restrict_eq_zero_iff_ae_eq_zero_of_mem`.

Ok, I will change the naming as suggested.

But by preferred spelling, I meant whether the LHS or the RHS of this "iff" should be used as a hypothesis and conclusion of results. Currently, [`AEFinStronglyMeasurable.exists_set_sigmaFinite`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Function/StronglyMeasurable/Basic.html#MeasureTheory.AEFinStronglyMeasurable.exists_set_sigmaFinite) has a conclusion of the LHS form, and [`set_integral_eq_integral_of_ae_compl_eq_zero`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Integral/SetIntegral.html#MeasureTheory.set_integral_eq_integral_of_ae_compl_eq_zero) has a hypothesis of the RHS form. This mismatch is why combining the two is not a one-liner.

I realize it might have been clearer if had I tagged the lemma type instead of the lemma name for this question. The iff is:
```
f =ᵐ[Measure.restrict μ s] 0 ↔ ∀ᵐ x ∂μ, x ∈ s → f x = 0 
```

And the question is which of the two sides of the iff is or should be "normal form"? If there is no preference, then the users are more often responsible for translating between the spellings. If there is a clear preference, I can mark the present lemma as `@[simp]` (possibly reversing the direction).
Don't mark this as `simp`, there is no clear direction which is better. I think the current direction is fine.

You shouldn't need `f_mble` here, as it is a consequence of `hs`.
```suggestion
    (hs : f =ᵐ[restrict μ sᶜ] 0) :
```

I failed to fix the proof without `(f_mble : NullMeasurable f μ)` or alternatively `(s_mble : MeasurableSet s)` (new lemma `integral_eq_integral_restrict'` below). For the latter I moreover needed a new `ae_restrict_eq_zero_iff_ae_eq_zero_of_mem'`.

Could you clarify how you intended to bypass all measurability requirements?

UPDATE: Sorry, I did not read my own NullMeasurability hypothesis correctly... This should be clear, I will fix! Thank you for the strengthening!

RE-UPDATE: No, I think I maintain that I don't see a fix after all. The problem is that I'm missing a proof of something like `ae_restrict_eq_zero_iff_ae_eq_zero_of_mem` or `ae_restrict_eq_zero_iff_ae_eq_zero_of_mem'` without any measurability hypotheses. Something like this is needed to deduce `f_mble` from `hs` as you suggested.
If a function `g` is null-measurable and a function `f` coincides ae with it, isn't `f` automatically null-measurable also? If not, discard my comment. If yes, apply this with `g = 0`.

You are right, of course. Sorry!

I will also reverse the direction of the equality and try to have a naming more in line with the lemmas just above this, of the form `set_integral_eq_integral_of_...`.

You don't need so many parentheses: it's more readable like that, I think.
```suggestion
    μ (f ⁻¹' t) = μ.restrict s (f ⁻¹' t) := by
```
I am not sure these 3 lemmas belong here, as they don't involve integrable functions. Move them to a more appropriate place?
Indeed, thanks. I moved to `MeasureSpace.lean`, which is where `Measure.restrict` is defined.

An update: I had to move two of these three to `SetIntegral.lean`, because `MeasureSpace.lean` was not imported there and they were used. But I suppose that file is still a better place than `L1Space.lean`.

```suggestion
lemma set_integral_eq_integral_of_ae_restrict_eq_zero (hs : f =ᵐ[μ.restrict sᶜ] 0) :
    ∫ ω in s, f ω ∂μ = ∫ ω, f ω ∂μ := by
  borelize E
```
could you replace zero here by an arbitrary constant in E (and remove the class `Zero E`)? The lemma name will need fixing.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Add a basic layercake formula for Bochner integral.
